newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks end higher but below 2,000 on CAC.
newsitem.headline: French stocks end higher but below 2,000 on CAC.

text.p: French shares finished firmer on Thursday but failed to breach 2,000 on the CAC-40 index, as market operators grew cautious ahead of U.S. jobless figures due on Friday.
The market got a lift from companies' first-half profits, which were well received, and strong German second-quarter growth statistics, which should feed through to the French economy, traders said.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed up 11.46 points or 0.58 percent at 1,996.23, while the CAC-40 futures contract was up at 2,003 from 1992 on Wednesday's close.
Volume was a respectable 3.59 billion francs.

Christian Noyer, a senior aide to Economy Minister Jean Arthuis, reaffirmed that France would meet its Maastricht treaty target of three percent of GDP by 1997. Paris must meet that goal to join a single European currency in 1999.

He added that France and Germany both had growth of 0.7 percent over the first half and that the question was whether France would see growth of between 1.5-two percent, or stronger growth of 2.5 or three percent.
But the mood in equities was cautious and operators would watch tomorrow's U.S. jobless data for clues on the next move on U.S. interest rates.

Food group Danone rises 29 francs to 721 on broker upgrades. Goldman Sachs upgraded Danone to "trading buy" from "market performer," while Societe Generale Delahaye upped it to "outperform" from "neutral".

Several stocks traded on expectations of a shakeup of the constituents of the CAC-40 index. Among risers who might join the index were steel producer Usinor-Sacilor, up 3.05 at 75.95, caterer Sodexho up 60 to 2,458, insurer AGF up 2.90 at 134.60, consumer finance house Cetelem up four to 1,051.
